{"step_by_step_thinking": "Septic shock is a severe systemic response to infection that can lead to organ failure and death. It is characterized by hypotension, tachycardia, and fever. The pathogenesis of septic shock involves the release of various cytokines in response to the infection. Among the options given, Tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of septic shock. It is released by macrophages and other immune cells in response to bacterial endotoxins and other microbial products. TNF-α promotes inflammation, coagulation, and cell death, contributing to the systemic effects of septic shock. The other cytokines listed, Interleukin-5, Interleukin-12, and Interleukin-4, are also involved in immune responses, but they do not play a direct role in the pathogenesis of septic shock.", "answer_choice": "A. Tumor necrosis factor-α"}
